paragraphs.text: THE CHURCH​
Night Watch Handbook
THE NIGHT WATCH​
Guardians of Consent, Keepers of the Flesh.

Welcome, Watchers. You are now part of the Church’s Night Watch, a sacred order devoted to keeping our upstairs playspace safe, consensual, and positively pulsing with sin. When you take on this role, you step into a mantle of care, presence, and authority.

You will be visible by your red-coded regalia: a cape and a headpiece with glowing red lights. Not just costume, this is your halo. Own it. Let people know who they can come to. Let your presence radiate: "We are watching because we care."
ON SHIFT
Your job is simple, holy, and serious:
●​ Welcome visitors at the playspace entrance (above the dancefloor).
●​ Ensure everyone who enters is in a good state of mind, sober enough to consent.
●​ Confirm visitors are entering in groups of 2 or more, with the intention of playing with each other.
●​ Do regular vibe checks inside the space.
●​ Intervene gently when something seems off.
Our playspace is sacred. Not a club. Not a cruise zone. A curated den of decadence.
Shifts are always done in pairs. Brothers and sisters of the Watch never walk alone. Support each other.

While you are on shift, you are welcome to enjoy the dancefloor, feel the music, move your body, but always stay attentive to any problem that may arise in or around the playspace. Let your joy never dull your vigilance.
If you cannot make your shift, find a replacement. God might provide, but you shall too.

Understand your role. Your presence is safety for those enjoying the playspace. When you do your checks of the space, think that you are there to remind them that they will have support if they need it.
COMMUNICATION & SUPPORT
The Night Watch is the authority in the playspace. You are empowered to act.
Use the walkie-talkies to communicate with:
●​ Fellow Watchers.
●​ Church brothers and sisters on site.
If something happens that must be known, inform a member of the Church crew. No logbooks here. Just speak your truth.
If nothing happened, let them know that too. No drama is still good data.
THE PANIC BUTTON
Our playspace has a panic button. It is sacred. If someone presses it, a signal will light up in the DJ booth. This will alert The Night Watch to step in and offer support.
Anyone can press it, Watcher, visitor, or clergy. Trust its purpose. Use it wisely.
PLAYSPACE RULES & ETIQUETTE
These commandments should be communicated as part of every welcome, or checked that their will is being fulfilled:
●​ Must arrive in groups of 2+ intending to play with each other
●​ Must have valid BL wristbands and be 18+
●​ Must appear sober and grounded
●​ Must agree to vibe checks and interventions if necessary
●​ No photography, phones, or filming
●​ No sleeping in the space
●​ No open drinks, drugs, smoking or flames
●​ Bring your own towel/blanket
●​ Clean up after yourself (Leave No Trace)
●​ No CNC, no blood play, watersports or scat
●​ No means NO. Escalation = explicit consent.
●​ The playspace is for play, if people want to chat, there are endless other places to be.
●​ COCOON is the safe word. If it is called and not respected, intervene immediately
Consent is sacred. It must be:​
Freely given, Reversible, Informed, Enthusiastic, Specific. (FRIES!)
WHAT TO WATCH FOR
Every 10–15 minutes, take a quiet tour of the space. You’re watching for:
●​ Signs of non-consent: freeze, silence, stiffness, tears
●​ Escalation without clear consent
●​ Visitors falling unconscious or overly intoxicated
●​ Solo cruising behavior
●​ Unwelcome spectators
●​ Drug use
●​ Anyone who makes the vibe shift toward discomfort
If in doubt: Check in. Gently. Clearly. Respectfully. And remember to approach your care as a gift. By being there and offering safety, you are helping the community feel at home and protected.
WHEN IN DOUBT
●​ Use the walkie to speak to your fellow Watchers or a Church crew member.
●​ If it’s serious, you are empowered to close the space temporarily.
●​ Escalate to the Borderland Consent Team or Clown Police if necessary
